subject: Re: [junit] Is it really neccessery to use Junit with some kind of IDE ?
msgSnippet: ... I wasn t trying to infer that anyone should completely avoid using an IDE for development. I was stating that it is not necessary to use an IDE to run a
messageBody:
On 12/8/05, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@...> wrote:
> On 12/8/05, Simon Chappell <simonpeterchappell@...> wrote:
> >
> > On 12/7/05, viveksaxena1975 <viveks@...> wrote:
> > > I havnt yet started using Junit, I am just considering.
> > > I need to develop test suite based on Unix and I dont want to use IDE.
> > > is that OK ?
> >
> > Yes.
> >
> > Further than that, I recommend it. Where I work, we always perform
> > builds (and the running of their JUnit tests) for deployment to our
> > application servers on dedicated build machines. We never perform
> > deployment builds on a developer's workstation; far too many unknowns
> > and differences between developers and what they do to their machines.
>
>
> The two are not mutually exclusive.
>
> Everybody around me uses an IDE and while they are doing development, they
> build everything inside the IDE and when they are ready to check in, they
> move to the shell/command prompt and build with ant to make sure they are
> not breaking anything.
>
> I *strongly* recommend using an IDE, and not just for JUnit. Maybe you
> think you are productive with your current text editor (emacs, vi, TextEdit,
> etc...) but I guarantee that your productivity will shoot up with an IDE.

I wasn't trying to infer that anyone should completely avoid using an
IDE for development. I was stating that it is not necessary to use an
IDE to run a test suite. Further, I recommend not using an IDE for
running test suites. Now, using an IDE for coding and individual unit
tests during development can make sense, although I still use mostly
text editors. :-)

Simon
